description:
Solea senegalensis, commonly known as the Senegalese sole or Senegal sole, is a species of flatfish belonging to the family Soleidae. It is native to the eastern Atlantic Ocean, primarily found along the coastlines of West Africa, from Mauritania to Angola.

Solea senegalensis is a benthic marine fish, meaning it lives and feeds on the seafloor. It has a unique flattened body shape, with both eyes situated on the upper, pigmented side of the body. This adaptation allows the fish to effectively camouflage itself against the seafloor, providing protection from predators and facilitating its ambush-style hunting strategy.

The Senegalese sole is a valuable commercial species, prized for its delicate, white flesh. It is an important component of the artisanal and industrial fisheries in the regions where it is found. Due to its economic importance, Solea senegalensis is also a subject of aquaculture research and development, with efforts to establish sustainable farming practices.

From a scientific perspective, Solea senegalensis is of interest for its unique morphological adaptations, its ecological role in benthic ecosystems, and its potential for aquaculture applications. Ongoing research aims to further understand the biology, population dynamics, and conservation status of this important flatfish species.
